communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Meta-FOIA DMD Calendars
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All records created by ICE in response to the FOIA request assigned individualized tracking number 2023-ICFO-15203. Please specifically task a search for C. Martinez and Joshua Farnkopf, Esq., as well as any FOIA talkers and responses sent or received by ICE FOIA between February 23, 2023, and April 5, 2023. 

We make this request on behalf of Al Otro Lado’s #DetentionKills Transparency Initiative. 

Thank you.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Free

communications.subject: ICE FOIA 2023-ICFO-20828
communications.communication:
04/17/2023Andrew FreeMuckRock News, DEPT MR144290Boston, Massachusetts 02115RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2023-ICFO-20828        Dear Requester:This acknowledges receipt of your 4/6/2023, Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), for all records created by ICE in response to the FOIA request assigned individualized tracking number 2023-ICFO-15203. Please specifically task a search for C. Martinez and Joshua Farnkopf, Esq., as well as any FOIA talkers and responses sent or received by ICE FOIA between February 23, 2023, and April 5, 2023. Your request was received in this office on 4/6/2023.Due to the increasing number of FOIA requests received by this office, we may encounter some delay in processing your request. Per Section 5.5(a) of the DHS FOIA regulations, 6 C.F.R. Part 5, ICE processes FOIA requests according to their order of receipt. Although ICE’s goal is to respond within 20 business days of receipt of your request, the FOIA does permit a 10-day extension of this time period. As your request seeks numerous documents that will necessitate a thorough and wide-ranging search, ICE will invoke a 10-day extension for your request, as allowed by Title 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(B). If you’re able to narrow the scope of your request please contact our office. Narrowing the scope may speed up the search process. We will make every effort to comply with your request in a timely manner.Provisions of the FOIA allow us to recover part of the cost of complying with your request.  We shall charge you for records in accordance with the DHS Interim FOIA regulations, as they apply to media requesters.  As a media requester, you will be charged 10 cents per page for duplication; the first 100 pages are free.  We will construe the submission of your request as an agreement to pay up to $25.00. You will be contacted before any further fees are accrued.We have queried the appropriate program offices within ICE for responsive records. If any responsive records are located, they will be reviewed for determination of releasability. Please be assured that one of the processors in our office will respond to your request as expeditiously as possible. We appreciate your patience as we proceed with your request.If you have any questions, please contact FOIA Public Liaison, Fernando Pineiro Jr. at the address above or (866) 633-1182. Additionally, you have a right to seek dispute resolution services from the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) which mediates disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation.  If you are requesting access to your own records (which is considered a Privacy Act request), you should know that OGIS does not have the authority to handle requests made under the Privacy Act of 1974.  You may contact OGIS as follows:  Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448; or facsimile at 202-741-5769.Your request has been assigned reference number 2023-ICFO-20828. Please use this number in future correspondence. Sincerely,ICE FOIA OfficeImmigration and Customs EnforcementFreedom of Information Act Office500 12th Street, S.W., Stop 5009Washington, D.C. 20536-5009 
This message (including any attachments) contains confidential information intended for a specific individual and purpose, and is protected by law. If you are not the intended recipient, you should delete this message and any disclosure, copying, or distribution
 of this message, or the taking of any action based on it, by you is strictly prohibited. 
Deloitte refers to a Deloitte member firm, one of its related entities, or Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu Limited ("DTTL"). Each Deloitte member firm is a separate legal entity and a member of DTTL. DTTL does not provide services to clients. Please see www.deloitte.com/about
 to learn more. 
v.E.1

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: 2023: Personnel Files, School-Based Staff
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

Please supply the full personnel files of the following individuals:

*Sandra Moy, current CPS teacher
*Scott Koenaman, security officer, Budlong Elementary
*Danielle Rutkowski, current CPS teacher
*Alesia Maria Franklin-Allen, current CPS Principal

This includes any resumes, applications, any job recommendations, promotions, professional license credentials and verification records. Please include a work/salary history. Please include any investigative materials - investigative memorandums, disciplinary actions (suspensions, leaves of absence that stem from disciplinary action), incident reports, EOCO investigations, Office of Civil Rights determinations, non-disciplinary memorandum of understandings, non-union misconduct form, full warning resolutions and any complaints or claims/lawsuits/settlements. Please include any safety plans. Please include any separation agreements and any other disclosure agreements.

Because this request is in the public interest for Illinois nonprofit The FOIA Bakery’s work to advocate for public education, please waive any fees in accordance with 5 ILCS § 140/6(c). Feel free to contact me with any questions, or if clarification is needed.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Miriam Bhimani

communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

08/29/2023 

Miriam Bhimani 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR151293 263 Huntington Ave 
Boston MA 02115 

Dear Miriam: 

RE: Chicago Public Schools FOIA Request N014122-082823 
Thank you again for using the Chicago Public Schools FOIA Center. 
Under the Freedom of Information Act, a public body may extend the time to respond to a FOIA request by up to 5 business days for a limited number of reasons. 5 ILCS 140/3(e). 
We are extending the time to respond to your request by 5 business days for one or more of the following reason(s): 
(  ) the requested records are stored in whole or in part at other locations than the office having charge of the requested records; 
( )  the request requires the collection of a substantial number of specified records; 
( ) the request is couched in categorical terms and requires an extensive search for the records responsive to it; 
( ) the requested records have not been located in the course of routine search and additional efforts are being made to locate them; 
(x) the requested records require examination and evaluation by personnel having the necessary competence and discretion to determine if they are exempt from disclosure under Section 7 of this Act or should be revealed only with appropriate deletions; 
(x) the request for records cannot be complied with by the public body within the time limits prescribed by 5 ILCS 140/3 (c) without unduly burdening or interfering with the operations of the public body; 
() there is need for consultation, which shall be conducted with all practicable speed, with another public body or among two or more components of a public body having a substantial interest in the determination or in the subject matter of the request. 

Sincerely, 

Patricia Majchrowicz 
FOIA Officer 
Chicago Public Schools 

Please note that District Offices will be closed on Monday, September 4th in observance of Labor Day.

*Scott Koenaman, security officer, Budlong Elementary

*Alesia Maria Franklin-Allen, current CPS Principal 

This includes any resumes, applications, any job recommendations, promotions, professional license credentials and verification records. Please include a work/salary history. Please include any investigative materials - investigative memorandums, disciplinary actions (suspensions, leaves of absence that stem from disciplinary action), incident reports, EOCO investigations, Office of Civil Rights determinations, non-disciplinary memorandum of understandings, non-union misconduct form, full warning resolutions and any complaints or claims/lawsuits/settlements. Please include any safety plans. Please include any separation agreements and any other disclosure agreements. 

Because this request is in the public interest for Illinois nonprofit The FOIA Bakery’s work to advocate for public education, please waive any fees in accordance with 5 ILCS § 140/6(c). Feel free to contact me with any questions, or if clarification is needed. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fchicago-public-schools-3121%252F2023-personnel-files-school-based-staff-151293%252F%253F&url_auth_token=AAATZ1CCn_QB9jem9PQylx6L91s%3A1qanxm%3Am46Tdf0iF0_MhizGB5lJza1_XmwVun2H1Sp2O7r_pSU 
RESPONSE: Documents responsive to your request are available to download via the CPS FOIA Center at www.cps.edu/FOIARequests . Please log in with your username and password to access the records. Please note that certain private information (personal descriptions, employee ID numbers, college transcripts, social security numbers, signatures, personal addresses, etc.) was redacted pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/7. Specifically, section 7(1)(b) which exempts certain private information as defined by section 2(c-5) and section 7(1)(c) which exempts personal information contained within public records, the disclosure of which would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, unless the disclosure is consented to in writing by the individual subject of the information. “Unwarranted invasion of personal privacy” means the disclosure of information that is highly personal or objectionable to a reasonable person and in which the subject’s right to privacy outweighs any legitimate public interest in obtaining the information. 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(a) exempts “ information specifically prohibited from disclosure by federal or State Law … ” (5 ILCS 140/7(1)(a)) Specifically, 105 ILCS 5/10-21.9 (b) states that “ any information concerning the record of convictions obtained by the president of the school board or the regional superintendent shall be confidential and may only be transmitted to the superintendent of the school district or his designee, the appropriate regional superintendent if the check was requested by the school district, the presidents of the appropriate school boards if the check was requested from the Department of State Police by the regional superintendent, the State Superintendent of Education, the State Teacher Certification Board, any other person necessary to the decision of hiring the applicant for employment, or for clarification purposes the Department of State Police or Statewide Sex Offender Database, or both.” 
Portions of this request that include personnel evaluations are redacted entirely in accordance with section 7(1)(a) of FOIA (5 ILCS 140/7(1)(a)) which exempts from public release information specifically prohibited from disclosure by federal or State law or rules and regulations implementing federal or State law and also in accordance with section 7.5(q) of the FOIA (5 ILCS 140/7.5(q)) which exempts from public release information prohibited from being disclosed by the Personnel Records Review Act [820 ILCS 40/0.01 et seq.] Certain records are being withheld entirely pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(f) as factual information inextricably intertwined in ongoing investigation and processes as well as 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(n), which exempts from release records relating to the adjudication of employee discipline and grievance matters except for records reflecting the final outcome. Section 7(d)(iv) of the FOIA which exempts confidential information furnished only by the confidential source, or persons who file complaints with or provide information to administrative, investigative, law enforcement, or penal agencies. Redactions have been made pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/7.5 (r), which exempts from inspection or copying information prohibited from being disclosed by the Illinois School Student Records Act (ISSRA). ISSRA prohibits the disclosure of students and any student records in which a student may be individually identified by a school regardless of how or where the information pursuant to (105 ILCS 10/2(d). Certain incident report entries related to this request are being withheld entirely pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(a). This section exempts from disclosure information specifically prohibited from disclosure by federal or State law or rules and regulations implementing federal or State law. Specifically, the Abused and Neglected Child Reporting Act, section 325 ILCS 5/1, states that all records concerning reports of child abuse and neglect or records concerning referrals under this Act and all records generated as a result of such reports or referrals, shall be confidential and shall not be disclosed except as specifically authorized by this Act or other applicable law; and 820 ILCS 40/13 of the Illinois Personel Records Review Act, which prohibits the identification of individuals who are the subject of an unfounded DCFS report. You have a right to have the denial of your request reviewed by the Public Access Counselor (PAC) at the Office of the Illinois Attorney General. 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a). You can file your Request for Review with the PAC by writing to: 
Public Access Counselor Office of the Attorney General 500 South 2nd Street Springfield, Illinois 62706 Fax: 217-782-1396 E-mail: publicaccess@atg.state.il.us You also have the right to seek judicial review of your denial by filing a lawsuit in the State circuit court. 5 ILCS 140/11. If you choose to file a Request for Review with the PAC, you must do so within 60 calendar days of the date of this denial letter. 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a). Please note that you must include a copy of your original FOIA request and this denial letter when filing a Request for Review with the PAC. Sincerely, 
Patricia Majchrowicz FOIA Officer Chicago Public Schools

title: John Hancock College Preparatory High School Personnel Files

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: John Hancock College Preparatory High School Personnel Files
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

Please supply the full personnel files of the following individuals:

--- Please respond above this line --- 

08/28/2023 

Alejandro Ruizesparza 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR151199 263 Huntington Ave 
Boston MA 02115 

Dear Alejandro: 

RE: Chicago Public Schools FOIA Request N014101-082423 
Thank you again for using the Chicago Public Schools FOIA Center. 
Under the Freedom of Information Act, a public body may extend the time to respond to a FOIA request by up to 5 business days for a limited number of reasons. 5 ILCS 140/3(e). 
We are extending the time to respond to your request by 5 business days for one or more of the following reason(s): 
(  ) the requested records are stored in whole or in part at other locations than the office having charge of the requested records; 
( )  the request requires the collection of a substantial number of specified records; 
( ) the request is couched in categorical terms and requires an extensive search for the records responsive to it; 
( ) the requested records have not been located in the course of routine search and additional efforts are being made to locate them; 
(x) the requested records require examination and evaluation by personnel having the necessary competence and discretion to determine if they are exempt from disclosure under Section 7 of this Act or should be revealed only with appropriate deletions; 
(x) the request for records cannot be complied with by the public body within the time limits prescribed by 5 ILCS 140/3 (c) without unduly burdening or interfering with the operations of the public body; 
() there is need for consultation, which shall be conducted with all practicable speed, with another public body or among two or more components of a public body having a substantial interest in the determination or in the subject matter of the request. 

Sincerely, 

Patricia Majchrowicz 
FOIA Officer 
Chicago Public Schools 

Please note that District Offices will be closed on Monday, September 4th in observance of Labor Day.

Thank you for using the Chicago Public Schools FOIA Center. You requested the following: 
To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records: 

Please supply the full personnel files of the following individuals: 

- Vanessa Puentes, former principal at John Hancock College Preparatory High School (JHCPHS) 
- Froylan Jimenez, current CPS teacher and JHCPHS LSC member 
- Abla Ayesh, current CPS teacher and JHCPHS LSC member

This includes any resumes, applications, any job recommendations, promotions, professional license credentials and verification records. Please include a work/salary history. Please include any investigative materials - investigative memorandums, disciplinary actions (suspensions, leaves of absence that stem from disciplinary action), incident reports, EOCO investigations, Office of Civil Rights determinations, non-disciplinary memorandum of understandings, non-union misconduct form, full warning resolutions and any complaints or claims/lawsuits/settlements. Please include any safety plans. Please include any separation agreements and any other disclosure agreements. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fchicago-public-schools-3121%252Fjohn-hancock-college-preparatory-high-school-personnel-files-151199%252F%253F&url_auth_token=AAATZ1CCn_QB9jem9PQylx6L91s%3A1qZMog%3Ax2bvkJZqpBtTLelLeeQXyfq9mxiz4De0W-DGBrE2PrQ 
RESPONSE: Documents responsive to your request are available to download via the CPS FOIA Center at www.cps.edu/FOIARequests . Please log in with your username and password to access the records. Please note that certain private information (personal descriptions, employee ID numbers, college transcripts, social security numbers, signatures, personal addresses, etc.) was redacted pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/7. Specifically, section 7(1)(b) which exempts certain private information as defined by section 2(c-5) and section 7(1)(c) which exempts personal information contained within public records, the disclosure of which would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, unless the disclosure is consented to in writing by the individual subject of the information. “Unwarranted invasion of personal privacy” means the disclosure of information that is highly personal or objectionable to a reasonable person and in which the subject’s right to privacy outweighs any legitimate public interest in obtaining the information. 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(a) exempts “ information specifically prohibited from disclosure by federal or State Law … ” (5 ILCS 140/7(1)(a)) Specifically, 105 ILCS 5/10-21.9 (b) states that “ any information concerning the record of convictions obtained by the president of the school board or the regional superintendent shall be confidential and may only be transmitted to the superintendent of the school district or his designee, the appropriate regional superintendent if the check was requested by the school district, the presidents of the appropriate school boards if the check was requested from the Department of State Police by the regional superintendent, the State Superintendent of Education, the State Teacher Certification Board, any other person necessary to the decision of hiring the applicant for employment, or for clarification purposes the Department of State Police or Statewide Sex Offender Database, or both.” 
Portions of this request that include personnel evaluations are redacted entirely in accordance with section 7(1)(a) of FOIA (5 ILCS 140/7(1)(a)) which exempts from public release information specifically prohibited from disclosure by federal or State law or rules and regulations implementing federal or State law and also in accordance with section 7.5(q) of the FOIA (5 ILCS 140/7.5(q)) which exempts from public release information prohibited from being disclosed by the Personnel Records Review Act [820 ILCS 40/0.01 et seq.] Redactions have been made pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/7.5 (r), which exempts from inspection or copying information prohibited from being disclosed by the Illinois School Student Records Act (ISSRA). ISSRA prohibits the disclosure of students and any student records in which a student may be individually identified by a school regardless of how or where the information pursuant to (105 ILCS 10/2(d). Redactions have also been made in accordance with 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(j)(iii) which exempts from release information concerning a school or university’s adjudication of student disciplinary cases, but only to the extent that disclosure would unavoidably reveal the identity of the student. 
Please also note that certain incident report entries related to this request are being withheld entirely pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(a). This section exempts from disclosure information specifically prohibited from disclosure by federal or State law or rules and regulations implementing federal or State law. Specifically, the Abused and Neglected Child Reporting Act, section 325 ILCS 5/1, states that all records concerning reports of child abuse and neglect or records concerning referrals under this Act and all records generated as a result of such reports or referrals, shall be confidential and shall not be disclosed except as specifically authorized by this Act or other applicable law; and 820 ILCS 40/13 of the Illinois Personel Records Review Act, which prohibits the identification of individuals who are the subject of an unfounded DCFS report. 
Section 7(1)(n) of the FOIA exempts from release “Records relating to a public body's adjudication of employee grievances or disciplinary cases. Records of discipline more than four years old are exempt from disclosure pursuant to section 7.5(q) of the FOIA (5 ILCS 140/7.5(q)), which exempts information prohibited from being disclosed by the Personnel Records Review Act [820 ILCS 40/0.01 et seq.]. 820 ILCS 40/8 of the Personnel Records Review Act states that “an employer shall review a personnel record before releasing information to a third party and, except when the release is ordered to a party in a legal action or arbitration, delete disciplinary reports, letters of reprimand, or other records of disciplinary action which are more than 4 years old.” 
You have a right to have the denial of your request reviewed by the Public Access Counselor (PAC) at the Office of the Illinois Attorney General. 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a). You can file your Request for Review with the PAC by writing to: 
Public Access Counselor Office of the Attorney General 500 South 2nd Street Springfield, Illinois 62706 Fax: 217-782-1396 E-mail: publicaccess@atg.state.il.us You also have the right to seek judicial review of your denial by filing a lawsuit in the State circuit court. 5 ILCS 140/11. If you choose to file a Request for Review with the PAC, you must do so within 60 calendar days of the date of this denial letter. 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a). Please note that you must include a copy of your original FOIA request and this denial letter when filing a Request for Review with the PAC. Sincerely, 
Patricia Majchrowicz FOIA Officer Chicago Public Schools

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: V-safe logs and modifications
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Server logs related to the V-safe program from January 1, 2023, to August 30, 2023.
2. Documentation detailing any software modifications, updates, or changes made to the V-safe program that led to its discontinuation of collecting new adverse event reports related to COVID-19 vaccines.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jackson Parker

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #23-01724-FOIA
communications.communication:
Dear Roger Andoh,

I am writing to follow up on my Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request dated August 30, 2023, concerning the V-safe program. My request was assigned the number 23-01724-FOIA and placed in your complex processing queue.

I hereby request expedited processing of my FOIA request in accordance with the U.S. Department of Justice's guidelines for the following reasons:

Imminent Threat to Life or Physical Safety: The V-safe program is directly related to the monitoring of adverse events following COVID-19 vaccination. Given the ongoing pandemic and the critical nature of vaccine safety, timely access to this information could be life-saving for individuals considering vaccination.

Urgency to Inform the Public: The V-safe program involves actual federal government activity that is of urgent concern to the public. The sooner this information is released, the sooner the public can make informed decisions about their health.

Widespread and Exceptional Media Interest: The COVID-19 pandemic and vaccination efforts are subjects of exceptional media interest. The integrity of the V-safe program and how it has been managed could significantly affect public confidence in the government's handling of the pandemic.

Given these compelling reasons, I also request a rolling release of records as they become available. This would serve the public interest by providing critical information as quickly as possible.

communications.subject: FOIA Request Tracking Number Change for Request DOC-OS-2018-000591 (to DOC-IOS-2018-000591)
communications.communication:
The FOIA request DOC-OS-2018-000591 has had its Tracking Number changed to DOC-IOS-2018-000591.  This is normally due to the request being transferred to another agency (for example, EPA to Dept. of Commerce) or to a sub-agency to process it. Additional details for this request are as follows: 
  * Old Tracking Number:					DOC-OS-2018-000591 
  * New Tracking Number:					DOC-IOS-2018-000591 
  * Requester Name:					Jimmy Tobias 
  * Date Submitted:					01/18/2018 
  * Long Description:					To Whom It May Concern: This is a request under the Freedom of Information Act. I hereby request the following records: Any and all available calendars, daily itineraries, and schedules of activities for Assistant Secretary Michael Platt, Jr. since he took office in August 2017. I am a reporter for The Nation magazine, and the requested documents will be made available to the general public. This request is not being made for commercial purposes. In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires. Sincerely, Jimmy Tobias

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #DOC-OS-2018-000591
communications.communication:
Hi Mr. Tobias,

Thank you for your inquiry regarding your FOIA request DOC-IOS-2018-000591.

We are experiencing a high volume of FOIA requests and back log in responding to FOIA requests.

Please know that your FOIA request is being processed with the utmost importance and as quickly and diligently as we can.

If you have any questions, I can be reached at 202-482-3257 or at BParsons@doc.gov<mailto:BParsons@doc.gov>.
Thanks,
Bobbie


Bobbie Parsons
FOIA Officer, Immediate Office of the Secretary
Office of Privacy and Open Government
Phone:  202-482-3257
E-mail:  BParsons@doc.gov

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #DOC-OS-2018-000591
communications.communication:
Hi Mr. Tobias,

Thank you for your email requesting status of your FOIA request DOC-IOS-2018-00593. We are down to waiting on 1 office unit to complete their search.  We are experiencing a significant increase in FOIA requests which in turn led to us experiencing a significant back log in our FOIA request responses.

We continue to work diligently to get your FOIA processed as quickly as we can.  If you have any questions, I can be reached at 202-482-3257 or at BParsons@doc.gov<mailto:BParsons@doc.gov%3cmailto:BParsons@doc.gov>.
Thanks,
Bobbie

FOIA Officer, Immediate Office of the Secretary
Office of Privacy and Open Government

Bobbie

& Deputy Director of Departmental FOIA/PA Operations

US Department of Commerce

communications.subject: Georgia Open Records Act Request: Open Records Request: Flock
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Copies of all invoices submitted by Flock Safety or containing the keyword "Flock" between the dates of January 1, 2017 and May 26, 2023.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

e

communications.subject: New Jersey Open Public Records Act Request: Open Records Request: Grant
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

On March 24, 2023, the State of New Jersey Office of the Attorney General issued a press release stating: "AG Platkin Announces 20 NJ Law Enforcement Agencies to Receive Grants Totaling $7 Million for Technology to Combat Gun Violence." The City of Atlanta City is listed as a recipient of a $333,700 grant. (https://www.njoag.gov/ag-platkin-announces-20-nj-law-enforcement-agencies-to-receive-grants-totaling-7-million-for-technology-to-combat-gun-violence/)

Pursuant to the New Jersey Open Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of all documents, including but not limited to, applications, agreements, and reporting documents for the City of Atlantic City's $333,700 grant awarded by the Office of Attorney General, Department of Law and Public Safety and described in the press release linked above.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

e

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: CoS Rich Giudice Calendar
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

Records sufficient to show the calendar entries for Chief of Staff Rich Giudice for the months of August 2023 and September 2023 to date. Please include entries from any/all calendars associated with Rich Giudice, not limited to his primary email account.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Anthony Moser

 September 28, 2023 Anthony Moser Via email at 152189-45772770@requests.muckrock.com RE: PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST of September 19, 2023, Reference # F056949-091923. Dear Anthony Moser, This correspondence is in response to the Freedom of Information Act ("FOIA") request received by the City of Chicago Office of the Mayor on September 19, 2023. The Office of the Mayor took a 5 business day extension to your request on September 27, 2023. You requested: "To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records: 

Records sufficient to show the calendar entries for Chief of Staff Rich Giudice for the months of August 2023 and September 2023 to date. Please include entries from any/all calendars associated with Rich Giudice, not limited to his primary email account. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Anthony Moser 

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fmayors-office-885%252Fcos-rich-giudice-calendar-152189%252F%253Femail%253DMOfoia%252540cityofchicago.org&url_auth_token=AAAVakss4kqDBu4naYY4htHES6U%3A1qioKt%3AOK5f73qJG_CutvwFczgLwvfrDgzyUZJON--8vvAI3UY" 
Please find the attached records responsive to your request. We have redacted certain material pursuant to Section 7(1)(b) of FOIA.  That section exempts “private information, unless disclosure is required by another provision of this Act, a State or federal law or a court order.”  5 ILCS 140/7(1)(b).  Section 2(c-5) defines “private information" as: 

unique identifiers, including a person's social security number, driver's license number, employee identification number, biometric identifiers, personal financial information, passwords or other access codes, medical records, home or personal telephone numbers, and personal email addresses. Private information also includes home address and personal license plates, except as otherwise provided by law or when compiled without possibility of attribution to any person. 

5 ILCS 140/2(c-5).  The material we have redacted under this section is access codes.  Because these items are specifically exempted under Section 7(1)(b), they have been properly redacted. 
We have redacted certain material pursuant to Section 7(1)(c) of FOIA.  That section exempts: 

[p]ersonal information contained within public records, the disclosure of which would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, unless the disclosure is consented to in writing by the individual subjects of the information.  ‘Unwarranted invasion of personal privacy’ means the disclosure of information that is highly personal or objectionable to a reasonable person and in in which the subject’s right of privacy outweighs any legitimate public interest in obtaining the information.  The disclosure of information that bears on the public duties of public employees and officials shall not be considered an invasion of personal privacy. 

We have redacted the identity of job applicants under Section 7(1)(c) of FOIA.  Individuals who go through an application process or examination process to attain a certain job or position have an expectation that this information would not be publicly disseminated if they are unsuccessful in attaining the position.  In 2011 PAC 13060, the PAC cited to an earlier decision to explain why release of all information relating to all unsuccessful applicants is exempt.  The PAC stated, “…the fact that an individual is seeking new employment for a position is information that a reasonable person would view as highly personal and the release of that information is likely to be viewed as objectionable by most individuals.  Publication of an individual’s application for a position can negatively impact that individual’s current employment….”  Also, in 2010 PAC 6243, the PAC held that the names of applicants who completed the Firefighter/EMT exam are exempt pursuant to Section 7(1)(c).  Thus, the Mayor's Office has properly redacted the identity of job applicants under Section 7(1)(c) of FOIA. You have the right to have a denial reviewed by the Public Access Counselor (PAC) at the Office of the Illinois Attorney General, 500 S. 2nd Street, Springfield, Illinois 62701, (877) 299-3642. You may also seek judicial review of a denial under 5 ILCS 140/11 of FOIA. If you have any questions or need additional information, please feel free to contact my office at 312-744-3844. Sincerely, Thomas Skelton 
FOIA Officer 
Mayor's Office

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Chicago Mayors' Fair Workweek Emails
communications.communication:
To whom it may concern,

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All emails and attachments sent or received by Mayors Rahm Emanuel or Lori Lightfoot during the period 1/1/2017–12/31/2021 that contain any of the following phrases: "fair workweek", "fair work week" or "fair scheduling".

This request is being made for non-commercial research purposes. The requested documents will be made available to the general public.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer that the request be filled electronically, if possible, by email attachment.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Peter Fugiel
Postdoctoral Research Fellow
Rutgers School of Management and Labor Relations

 May 15, 2023 Peter Fugiel Via email at 145180-13456560@requests.muckrock.com RE: PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST of April 30, 2023, Reference # F045481-043023. Dear Peter Fugiel, This correspondence is in response to the Freedom of Information Act ("FOIA") request received by the City of Chicago Office of the Mayor on April 30, 2023. The Office of the Mayor took a 5 business day extension to your request on May 8, 2023. You requested: "To whom it may concern, 

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records: 

All emails and attachments sent or received by Mayors Rahm Emanuel or Lori Lightfoot during the period 1/1/2017–12/31/2021 that contain any of the following phrases: "fair workweek", "fair work week" or "fair scheduling". 

This request is being made for non-commercial research purposes. The requested documents will be made available to the general public. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer that the request be filled electronically, if possible, by email attachment. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires. 

Peter Fugiel 
Postdoctoral Research Fellow 
Rutgers School of Management and Labor Relations 

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fmayors-office-885%252Fchicago-mayors-fair-workweek-emails-145180%252F%253Femail%253DMOfoia%252540cityofchicago.org&url_auth_token=AAAVakss4kqDBu4naYY4htHES6U%3A1ptIlR%3ATu306bisa7gmrkt41yCqXQQf8HKkbjhmFBhjx7X58-g" 
Your request is unduly burdensome under Section 3(g) of FOIA.  Section 3(g) of FOIA provides that “requests for all records falling within a category shall be complied with unless compliance with the request would be unduly burdensome for the complying public body and there is no way to narrow the request and the burden on the public body outweighs the public interest in the information.” 

I ran the email search you requested, but it returned 573 responsive emails and attachments totaling 4,334 pages of responsive records.  Assuming it would take between 1/2 to 1 minute on average to review each page of responsive records, it would take between 36 and 72 hours to review the records responsive to this request.  While there is some public interest in some of the information requested, the request places a high burden on the Mayor's Office's time and operations.  Overall, the burden on the Mayor's Office outweighs the public interest in the information, and the request is unduly burdensome under Section 3(g) of FOIA. 

It is necessary that your FOIA request be narrowed and clarified.  If you would like assistance in narrowing your request, please contact me, and I will assist you.  Otherwise, for the reasons provided above, the Mayor's Office is unable to respond to your FOIA request as currently drafted. 

If you agree to narrow your request, you must submit a revised written request to my attention. The Mayor's Office will take no further action or send you any further correspondence unless and until your current request is narrowed in writing.  If we do not receive your narrowed request within fourteen calendar days of the date of this letter, your current request will be denied. 

In the event that we do not receive a narrowed request and your current FOIA request is therefore denied, you have the right to have a denial reviewed by the Public Access Counselor (PAC) at the Office of the Illinois Attorney General, 500 S. 2nd Street, Springfield, Illinois 62706, (877) 299-3642. You also have the right to seek judicial review of your denial by filing a lawsuit in Cook County Circuit Court. 
If you have any questions or need additional information, please feel free to contact my office at 312-744-3844. Sincerely, Thomas Skelton 
FOIA Officer 
Mayor's Office

communications.subject: RE: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request #F045481-043023
communications.communication:
Dear Thomas Skelton,

Thank you for your initial response to this request. I recognize the need to balance the burden of fulfilling the request and the public interest in the information. While the latter side of the ledger is difficult to estimate as precisely as you have the former, I would note that the Chicago Fair Workweek Ordinance represents the most expansive labor standard of its kind. Along with a handful of other cities and one state, Chicago has established the most significant new rights and protections on working time since the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. My research seeks to understand the development and implementation of fair workweek laws, a project in which the National Science Foundation found sufficient merit to award me a competitive research fellowship (#2203815).

Notwithstanding the considerable public interest in this information, I am willing to narrow my request to the period 1/1/2018–12/31/2019. I would still like a copy, preferably in electronic format, of all emails and attachments sent or received by Mayors Emmanuel or Lightfoot during the specified period that contain either of the phrases "fair workweek" or "fair scheduling."

I appreciate your continued assistance and look forward to your response to this narrowed request.

Sincerely,

Peter Fugiel
Postdoctoral Research Fellow
Rutgers School of Management & Labor Relations

I have requested a copy, preferably in electronic format, of all emails and attachments sent or received by Mayors Emanuel or Lightfoot during the the period 1/1/2018–12/31/2019 that contain either of the phrases "fair workweek" or "fair scheduling."

Thank you for your attention,
Peter Fugiel

communications.communication:
Hi Mr. Fugiel,

The request is not unduly burdensome.  However, I have a backlog of email requests that I am reviewing the records for.  Can we check back in two weeks to see where we are in the review?  I apologize for the delay, but I do not know how it would be fair to other requests if I did not review in the order I receive them for these.  Let me know if you have any questions.

Sincerely,



Tom Skelton | FOIA Officer, Office of the Mayor |d:  312-744-3844 | m:  312-859-1459

We have redacted certain material pursuant to Section 7(1)(b) of FOIA.  That section exempts “private information, unless disclosure is required by another provision of this Act, a State or federal law or a court order.”  5 ILCS 140/7(1)(b).  Section 2(c-5) defines “private information" as: 

unique identifiers, including a person's social security number, driver's license number, employee identification number, biometric identifiers, personal financial information, passwords or other access codes, medical records, home or personal telephone numbers, and personal email addresses. Private information also includes home address and personal license plates, except as otherwise provided by law or when compiled without possibility of attribution to any person. 

5 ILCS 140/2(c-5).  The material we have redacted under this section is personal email addresses and personal phone numbers.  Because these items are specifically exempted under Section 7(1)(b), they have been properly redacted. 
We have redacted certain material pursuant to Section 7(1)(c) of FOIA.  That section exempts: 

[p]ersonal information contained within public records, the disclosure of which would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, unless the disclosure is consented to in writing by the individual subjects of the information.  ‘Unwarranted invasion of personal privacy’ means the disclosure of information that is highly personal or objectionable to a reasonable person and in in which the subject’s right of privacy outweighs any legitimate public interest in obtaining the information.  The disclosure of information that bears on the public duties of public employees and officials shall not be considered an invasion of personal privacy. 
We have redacted under Section 7(1)(c) City issued cell phone numbers.  As publicly-available City issued cell phone numbers would subject these employees to invasive and unsolicited communications, the disclosure of this information would burden employees’ privacy interest. Additionally, the access to this information would not advance the public interest in understanding “the affairs of government and the official acts and policies of those who represent them[.]” 5 ILCS 140/1. Further, the landline numbers and other email addresses for these employees is available to the public, which further limits the de minimis public interest in the contact information of the requested employees. See Shurtleff v. United States Environmental Protection Agency, 991 F. Supp. 2d 1, 18 (D.D.C. Sept. 30, 2013) (“The EPA has proferred a substantial privacy interest at stake in disclosing the official internal email address of the EPA Administrator and the work email address of employees at the EOP: these few individuals have ‘a significant personal interest in preventing the burden of unsolicited emails and harassment.’”); Buckovetz v. U.S. Department of the Navy, Case No. 14-cv-2115-BEN, 2016 WL 4801335 at *2-3 (S.D. Cal. Apr. 7, 2016) (affirming the redaction of an employee’s cell phone number, because “the [employee’s] privacy rights in this information outweigh the public’s interest in disclosure”).” 
We have redacted and withheld certain material pursuant to Section 7(1)(f) of FOIA.  That section exempts: 

Preliminary drafts, notes, recommendations, memoranda and other records in which opinions are expressed, or policies or actions are formulated, except that a specific record or relevant portion of a record shall not be exempt when the record is publicly cited and identified by the head of the public body. 

5 ILCS 140/7(1)(f). The U.S. Supreme Court has determined that the deliberative process exemption under FOIA focuses on documents that reflect “advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated.” NLRB v. Sears and Roebuck, 421 U.S. 132, 150-151 (1975).  The purpose is to encourage “frank discussion of legal or policy matters” such that employees in government feel free to express their opinions before a final legal or policy decision is made. “Deliberative” has been found to mean being a direct part of the process where recommendations and opinions are expressed. Vaughn v. Rosen, 523 F.2d 1136, 1143-44 (D.C. Cir. 1975). Records where preliminary opinions are expressed and policies and actions are formulated are therefore exempt from production under Section 7(1)(f) of the Illinois FOIA, and have been properly redacted and withheld. 
We have redacted and withheld certain material pursuant to Section 7(1)(m) of FOIA.  That section exempts: 

Communications between a public body and an attorney or auditor representing the public body that would not be subject to discovery in litigation, and materials prepared or compiled by or for a public body in anticipation of a criminal, civil or administrative proceeding upon the request of an attorney advising the public body, and materials prepared or compiled with respect to internal audits of public bodies. 

5 ILCS 140/7(1)(m).  Because the redacted and withheld records constituted privileged communications between an attorney and clients, they have been properly redacted and withheld under this section. You have the right to have a denial reviewed by the Public Access Counselor (PAC) at the Office of the Illinois Attorney General, 500 S. 2nd Street, Springfield, Illinois 62701, (877) 299-3642. You may also seek judicial review of a denial under 5 ILCS 140/11 of FOIA. If you have any questions or need additional information, please feel free to contact my office at 312-744-3844. Sincerely, Thomas Skelton 
FOIA Officer 
Mayor's Office

communications.subject: RE: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request #F048062-060623
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Skelton,

Thank you for providing these records. I appreciate your summary of the various reasons for redacting or withholding certain information. I have a couple of clarifying questions to be sure that these are the entirely of the records responsive to my request. 

First, would you confirm that only one email (with the subject "Students Demand Action & Wisconsin Preemption - The DMO Digest") was sent or received by Mayor Emanuel during the period 1/1/2018–12/31/2019? For context, the Committee on Workforce Development and Audit, then chaired by Mayor Emanuel's floor leader Patrick O'Connor, held multiple meetings on the proposed Fair Workweek Ordinance in April 2018. Am I to understand that your search return no emails updating Mayor Emanuel of the status of this proposal in the final months of his term in office?

Second, could you clarify why certain email attachments ("Fair Workweek City Comparison 7.20.docx" and "BRIEF_0726_Osterman briefing.docx") were not included in the records provided? It is not clear to me that a document comparing provisions of existing fair workweek laws meets any of the statutory requirements for exemption. The laws are public, so why would a document quoting/summarizing them be withheld? Similarly, I don't understand why a briefing document mentioning fair workweek would not be subject to disclosure now that the law has been enacted and Alderman Osterman and Mayor Lightfoot have left office.

I would appreciate any clarification or additional records you can provide at this time. Given the considerable public interest in the Mayors' leadership around this major piece of policy, I may need to submit additional requests if this one is too narrow to yield relevant records, e.g. from the Emanuel administration.

Thank you for your continued attention to this matter,
Peter Fugiel
Postdoctoral Research Fellow
Rutgers School of Management and Labor Relations

communications.communication:
Hi Mr. Fugiel,

I think the briefing with Ald. Osterman you reference was a duplicate.  The chart was more than just copy and pasting other ordinances.  There was comparative analysis, which I think makes it deliberative.  Yes, I included Mayor Emanuel in this search.

Sincerely,

Tom Skelton | FOIA Officer, Office of the Mayor |d:  312-744-3844 | m:  312-859-1459
Follow Mayor Johnson on Instagram<https://www.instagram.com/chicagosmayor/>, Twitter<https://twitter.com/chicagosmayor>, and Facebook<https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=100092157126212&mibextid=LQQJ4d>.

communications.subject: RE: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request #F048062-060623
communications.communication:
Hi Mr. Skelton,

Thank you for those clarifications. Would you provide the "Fair Workweek City Comparison 7.20.docx" attachment with appropriate redactions? Surely there is factual information (i.e. which cities have what provisions in existing law) contained in the document that does not constitute deliberation. I believe the public has a right to know what information the Mayor considered, even if the preliminary opinions and discussions regarding this information remain confidential. 

I have already appealed to the Public Access Bureau for information inappropriately withheld by the City Council FOIA Officer. I hope that I will not have to do so again.

Sincerely,
Peter Fugiel

Hi Mr. Fugiel,

Yes, I provided all the responsive emails.  I reviewed the chart you mentioned and withheld it because it appeared deliberative under Section 7(1)(f).  I believed I provided a copy of the Osterman briefing but with talking points redacted.  There were two copies of the briefing, so I only reviewed one of them since they were duplicates of the same record.  There were over 500 pages of responsive email to review here.  I applied the redaction I thought were appropriate under the FOIA.  Let me know if you have any other questions.

Sincerely,



Tom Skelton | FOIA Officer, Office of the Mayor |d:  312-744-3844 | m:  312-859-1459

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Paula Sladewski Case (Miami Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all records/photos/videos/audio and other materials related to the disappearance and death investigation of Paula Sladewski. (Reported missing and body identified on January 3, 2010)

Including, but not limited to:
- Reports from Medical Examiner 
- Surveillance footage from approx 7am-8am from Space Club showing Kevin Klym and then Paula Sladewski leaving with an unknown male
- Incident reports from discovery of body
- Police reports about attempt to file missing person report
- Correspondence about FDLE taking over the case
- Other investigative reports

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Rob Vernier

title: King County Department of Permitting and Environmental Review (DPER) – Nine (9) email account messages for the time period 05-03-2014 to 10-12-2016

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: King County Department of Permitting and Environmental Review (DPER) – Nine (9) email account messages for the time period 05-03-2014 to 10-12-2016
communications.communication:
Public Records Act Request: King County Department of Permitting and Environmental Review (DPER) – Nine (9) email account messages for the time period 05-03-2014 to 10-12-2016

PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST RCW 42.56

I request the following identifiable public records to be produced in the following order of production:

A complete electronic copy of the following email accounts for the time period beginning on 05/03/2014 through 10/12/2016 for the following email account/addresses:

mary.impson@kingcounty.gov
david.bond@kingcounty.gov
toya.williams@kingcounty.gov
stacy.graves@kingcounty.gov
chris.ricketts@kingcounty.gov
sheryl.lux@kingcounty.gov
jim.chan@kingcounty.gov
rhonda.berry@kingcounty.gov
John Starbard - Director (County email address unknown)

To be clear in this request under RCW 42.56.10 I am requesting any and all internal and external KCDPER emails sent, received, and/or contained in the above referenced @kingcounty.gov email accounts for the time period 05/03/2014 to 10/12/2016.

In the event the Agency chooses to provide the records in installments over time I request the records to be produced in the order of priority as listed above.

If this request is redacted in whole or part, I ask that you justify all redactions by reference to specific exemptions of the PRA. I also request a detailed contemporaneous log to be provided for any document withheld or redacted.

For each responsive record the Agency contends is exempt from public disclosure, in whole or in part, please specifically identify the record by subject, title, author, custodian and date, and state how a specific statutory exemption applies to each record as required by RCW 42.56.210(3) and Rental Housing Ass'n v. Des Moines, 165 Wn.2d 525, 199 P.3d 393 (2009).

I request electronic production of all records in the original NATIVE electronic format for each record.

I request productions of all emails in native MICROSOFT .pst (personal storage table) format which allows for a virtually infinite number of emails to be produced in a single digital file, providing for economy and convenience. If the .pst format is not available, I would request production of email in .pdf (portable document format) another widely accepted format for email production providing similar economy and convenience of a virtually infinite number emails bundled into a single digital .pdf file.

I request records production by public (no password) e-mail attachment or link if available, or USB DRIVE or CD-ROM if not.

PRODUCTION AND DELIVERY OF ELECTRONIC RECORDS
The use of 3rd party “portals” (Such as GOVQA or NEXTREQUEST) for communication and production of records in response to a public records request is optional for the requestor in the State of Washington. Respectfully I decline to use any 3rd party "portal" system, specifically GOVQA and NEXTREQUEST. 

Please provide all records electronically via direct email attachment, or via no password, no registration internet cloud-based download link.

Please do not direct or invite me to use, register for, or communicate with your agency via any 3rd party portal including but not limited to FOIAOnline, GovQA, NextRequest, FOIAExpress, JustFOIA FOIADirect, WebForm, or any other commercial 3rd party records portal service.

RCW 42.56.080 - Identifiable records—Facilities for copying—Availability of public records.

"...Agencies shall honor requests received in person during an agency's normal office hours, or by mail or email, for identifiable public records unless exempted by provisions of this chapter. No official format is required for making a records request; however, agencies may recommend that requestors submit requests using an agency provided form or web page."

This public records request is being made via email. This public records request will be honored and fulfilled by your agency via email as requested or relief will be sought per statute.

NATIVE ELECTRONIC FORMAT

Please provide all identified public records in their NATIVE electronic format. Unless the records exist IN PAPER FORM ONLY, DO NOT instead create new records by printing native stored electronic files, then scanning and re-printing these newly scanned prints only to reproduce them in again in electronic production.

FEES

In the event that there are fees, please inform us of the total charges in advance of fulfilling the request in strict compliance with all provisions of the Washington State Public Records Act.

EXEMPTION LOGS
Please ensure all redactions or exemptions claimed by your agency in the production of responsive records are accompanied by a complete and detailed exemption log noting the valid legal reason for each exemption at each redaction location in the record produced, as well as the specific number of pages if any that your agency redacts or withholds in their entirety. Each redaction should be noted by footnote or by a clear reference to the specific justification for that redaction, and only the minimal exempt portion of any record may be withheld.

COMMERCIAL PURPOSE DECLARATION
The Washington State Public Records Act prohibits the disclosure of “lists of individuals” for a commercial purpose (RCW 42.56.070(8)). I declare this public records request is not being made for any commercial purpose whatsoever. Also, this public records request is not being made for a "list of individuals." This declaration satisfies all requirements of RCW 42.56 regarding prohibitions on lists and commercial purposes. No additional commercial purpose declaration will be completed for this public records request.
The requested documents will be made available to the general public.

THIS REQUEST IS NOT BEING MADE FOR COMMERCIAL PURPOSES.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

communications.communication:
08-16-23
To: King County Executive Branch
via email to kcexec@kingcounty.gov.
RE: tracking number G006992-081423

FYI - 

I filed a public records request with the King County Department Of Permitting And Environmental Review.

The King County Executive Branch responded via the email address: kingcountyexec@govqa.us

I was told: "Please reply to this email if you have any questions. Sincerely, King County Executive Branch."

I responded to "THIS EMAIL" - kingcountyexec@govqa.us . This email address rejected my email response. 

I need my questions answered within a reasonable amount of time.

THIS IS A PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST COMMUNICATION UNDER RCW 42.56.

Thank you.

----------------------------

From: King County Department Of Permitting And Environmental Review

08/16/2023
Subject: Unrecognized Email :: U019513-081623

Hello ,
You have responded to an unresponsive email.

Please be advised that if you wish to submit a public records request, update an existing request, or check the status of an already submitted request, you should visit the Public Records Center.

Thank you

----------------------------

Email
8-16-23

TO: King County Executive Branch
via email to: kingcountyexec@govqa.us
RE: tracking number G006992-081423

I do not understand. This public records request is addressed to King County Department of Permitting and Environmental Review (DPER) not to the King County Executive Branch.

The King County Department of Permitting and Environmental Review (DPER) website lists email address [PRA.Requests@kingcounty.gov] as the email address to submit public records requests, which I have done.

Website screenshot attached.

1. Are you responding to this request for The King County Department of Permitting and Environmental Review (DPER)?
2. What is the name and email address of the Public Records Officer for The King County Department of Permitting and Environmental Review (DPER)?

Thank you.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

Your request has been assigned tracking number G006992-081423.  Your request is for the following: "King County Department Of Permitting And Environmental Review 
Washington Public Records Act Office 
Suite 300 
919 SW Grady Way 
Renton, WA 98057 
August 14, 2023 
Public Records Act Request: King County Department of Permitting and Environmental Review (DPER) – Nine (9) email account messages for the time period 05-03-2014 to 10-12-2016 
PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST RCW 42.56 
I request the following identifiable public records to be produced in the following order of production: 
A complete electronic copy of the following email accounts for the time period beginning on 05/03/2014 through 10/12/2016 for the following email account/addresses: 
mary.impson@kingcounty.gov

communications.subject: FW: Washington Public Records Act Request #G006992-081423
communications.communication:
Dear Muckrock User:

The PRA.Requests@kingcounty.gov<mailto:PRA.Requests@kingcounty.gov> mailbox forwarded this email string to me.

I am sorry to hear that you are having technical difficulties. Responding to messages sent through GovQA using "reply" will be sent to kingcountyexec@govqa.us<mailto:kingcountyexec@govqa.us> and will post to the request. I do not see your response on request G006992-081423. I am the Public Records Officer for the Department of Local Service s- Permitting Division (formerly DPER,) and your request was assigned to me.  "King County Executive Branch" is not a department, but refers to the branch of local government (executive, legislative, judicial) and DLS-Permitting is within the executive branch. I have no explanation for the technical problems that you experienced when you attempted to reply to the 8/14/23 auto-generated message, and I have not heard of other users having this problem.

I responded to your request yesterday. Please confirm that you received this response, which I have cut from GovQA and pasted below:

communications.subject: FW: Washington Public Records Act Request #G006992-081423
communications.communication:
Dear Muckrock User,

The message below was sent via GovQA today.
_____________________________________________________________________________________

September 05, 2023
​
Re: G006992-081423
​
Dear Muckrock User:
​
Thank you again for the public records request which the King County Executive Branch received from you on August 14, 2023. We understand you are seeking the following records:
​
"King County Department Of Permitting And Environmental Review
Washington Public Records Act Office
Suite 300
919 SW Grady Way
Renton, WA 98057
August 14, 2023
Public Records Act Request: King County Department of Permitting and Environmental Review (DPER) – Nine (9) email account messages for the time period 05-03-2014 to 10-12-2016
PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST RCW 42.56
I request the following identifiable public records to be produced in the following order of production:
A complete electronic copy of the following email accounts for the time period beginning on 05/03/2014 through 10/12/2016 for the following email account/addresses:
mary.impson@kingcounty.gov<mailto:mary.impson@kingcounty.gov>
david.bond@kingcounty.gov<mailto:david.bond@kingcounty.gov>
toya.williams@kingcounty.gov<mailto:toya.williams@kingcounty.gov>
stacy.graves@kingcounty.gov<mailto:stacy.graves@kingcounty.gov>
chris.ricketts@kingcounty.gov<mailto:chris.ricketts@kingcounty.gov>
sheryl.lux@kingcounty.gov<mailto:sheryl.lux@kingcounty.gov>
jim.chan@kingcounty.gov<mailto:jim.chan@kingcounty.gov>
rhonda.berry@kingcounty.gov<mailto:rhonda.berry@kingcounty.gov>
John Starbard - Director (County email address unknown)

To be clear in this request under RCW 42.56.10 I am requesting any and all internal and external KCDPER emails sent, received, and/or contained in the above referenced @kingcounty.gov email accounts for the time period 05/03/2014 to 10/12/2016."
​
An initial installment of records responsive to your request is available to you now in a shared OneDrive folder. You will be asked to verify your email address and request a code in order to open the folder. This is a security feature that I am not able to override. If you are unable to receive a verification link email at 150701-33137398@requests.muckrock.com<mailto:150701-33137398@requests.muckrock.com> or do not find a code in your junk/span folder,  please provide another email address where you are able to receive the verification code. (I am simply trying to remove possible barriers to your access to the records, and I am not requesting your name or identity if you do not wish to share that information.)

The link to OneDrive:
​
[​Folder icon] G006992 Muckrock<https://kc1-my.sharepoint.com/:f:/g/personal/greg_felton_kingcounty_gov/EgW4PSB0tK5Jt8ObNlqGXCkB4qaEG51izBwuTVWDYpI-qg?email=150701-33137398%40requests.muckrock.com&e=x0Ks6l>
​
King County recently completed production of a very similar Public Records Act request that was opened in 2016, and most of the records produced for that request can be produced for you relatively quickly. However, King County did not review or produce Rhonda Berry's records for that request after the customer withdrew that portion of the request due to labor union objections to the release.
​
Our preliminary estimate is that researching, reviewing and producing Rhonda Berry's email records could take multiple installments over the course of 5 or more years. Unlike the other employees listed, Berry was not an employee of the Department of Local Services - Permitting Division (formerly DPER.) The department director, John Starbard, reported to Berry, but she was not involved in the day-to-day work of the division.
​
​In order to process these request items efficiently and expediently, please provide information for the following questions regarding Rhonda Berry's email records:

  *   Are you seeking Berry's email records regarding specific permits and/or code enforcement cases?
  *   Are you seeking records from a more specific time frame or date range?
  *   Are you seeking Berry's email records sent to/from particular staff members, or departments?
  *   Can you identify subjects or key words to help us locate the records you are seeking?
Please contact me at your earliest convenience about which types of Rhonda Berry records you are seeking.
​
We are currently gathering and reviewing records responsive to the remaining portions of your request, for the records of other employees that you listed. We anticipate providing you an installment of responsive records on approximately 09/26/2023.
​
Sincerely,
Greg Felton
Public Records Officer
DLS-Permitting Division
Greg.Felton@kingcounty.gov

We are still gathering all of the records for the remaining 8 email inboxes. The prior records request was completed in 33 installments with the help of a records database. The .pst files were labeled “PRODxxx” for the production numbers. I have uploaded 4 of the productions thus far and I have asked to have the remaining batches of productions downloaded from the database.


I anticipate having this all complete by October 12, but I will do my best to have them to you sooner. I will report back on or before September 26.

Sincerely,

Greg Felton
Public Records Officer
Department of Local Services (DLS) Permitting Division
206-477-3240

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request #G006992-081423
communications.communication:
09-07-23

via email to "Felton, Greg" <Greg.Felton@kingcounty.gov>

Mr. Felton,

Thank you that is helpful information. Of the thirty three (33) total installments you reference we have received "PROD016," "PROD017," "PROD018," and "PreDISCOInstallments." The numbered installments seem self explanatory, the PreDISCOInstallments file requires explanation. Is the PreDISCOInstallments file 1 of the 33 total files?

Thank you

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request #G006992-081423
communications.communication:
I received a copy of a paper letter from you dated 9/7 that read:

“Thank you, that is helpful information. Of the thirty three (33) total installments you reference we have received “PROD016,” “PROD017,” “PROD018” and “PreDISCOInstallments.” The numbered installments seem self explanatory, the PreDISCOInstallments file requires explanation. Is the PreDISCOInstallments file 1 of the 33 total files?”

It is a little complicated and my keeping the original naming convention did not make it very clear. My record shows that there were 38 installments of records produced in response to the 2016 request. Of the 38 installments, 5 were produced by staff and the next 33 were produced with the assistance of the Discovery database. Each one of the installments from Discovery was labeled a production, or PROD. (So PROD 001 from Discovery was actually installment 6, overall.) The file labeled “PreDISCOInstallments” contains the records produced in the first 5 installments, prior to King County using the Discovery database to review and produce later installments. The database manufacturer refers to their software as “DISCO,” which I used when naming that file. So in actuality you will receive 33 “production” files and the file named “PreDISCOInstallments” for a total of 34 separate files.

I could have renamed the PROD files to make it simpler, but keeping the original PROD names helped me stay organized and recognize the gaps in the records that I have available to me. We are still gathering the remaining productions from the DISCO database and I hope to get another batch to you within the next week.  I want to add that I did not receive a 9/7 email from you, so I apologize for the delay in responding to you. I don’t see a message in a junk folder so I’m not sure what happened. Fortunately, it appears  that you are able to receive email messages from me.

Sincerely,

Greg Felton | Public Records Officer | 206-477-3240
King County Department of Local Services, Permitting Division

9-27-23

Hello,

The link you sent over is password/registration protected and I cannot access it.


SEE ORIGINAL REQUEST:

PRODUCTION AND DELIVERY OF ELECTRONIC RECORDS
The use of 3rd party “portals” (Such as GOVQA or NEXTREQUEST) for communication and production of records in response to a public records request is optional for the requestor in the State of Washington. Respectfully I decline to use any 3rd party "portal" system, specifically GOVQA and NEXTREQUEST.

Please provide all records electronically via direct email attachment, or via no password, no registration internet cloud-based download link.

Please do not direct or invite me to use, register for, or communicate with your agency via any 3rd party portal including but not limited to FOIAOnline, GovQA, NextRequest, FOIAExpress, JustFOIA FOIADirect, WebForm, or any other commercial 3rd party records portal service.
